loveline.title: LoveLine
loveline.subtitle: Digital Picture Frame Messenger
loveline.tagline: A tiny 10Ã—10cm screen that lights up when your partner is thinking of you. Messages that live on your nightstand, not in your notification drawer.
loveline.description: A personal messenger with a physical 10cm display â€” like a tiny picture frame that shows messages from your loved one.

sections.context: LoveLine is a messenger, but not the kind that lives on your phone. It's a small physical picture frame â€” 10 by 10 centimeters â€” that sits on your desk or nightstand. When your partner sends you a message, it just appears. No notifications, no apps to open. Just a quiet little screen letting you know someone's thinking of you.
sections.problem: Texting feels throwaway. Messages disappear in a feed between work chats and group notifications. There's nothing physical, nothing that stays. Couples in long-distance relationships especially lack that sense of presence â€” the feeling of being in the same room.
sections.solution: A SvelteKit web app paired with an ESP32-powered display. You send a message or photo through the app, and it shows up instantly on the physical frame at your partner's place. Server-Sent Events keep everything real-time. An AI-powered date planner suggests things to do together, even from a distance.
sections.impact: A message that doesn't get buried. A screen you actually glance at because it only shows what matters. LoveLine turns a digital message into something that feels closer to a handwritten note left on the kitchen counter.

robotics.title: ABC Sensor Box
robotics.subtitle: Defence Embedded Systems
robotics.tagline: A universally mountable sensor box for the 1. ABC Umweltmessstelle â€” detecting radiation, gas, and oxygen levels in real-time over LoRa.
robotics.description: Universally mountable CBRN sensor box built for the ABC Abwehr Korneuburg with Geiger-MÃ¼ller counter, MQ gas sensors, and Oâ‚‚ monitoring.

sections.context: Built as part of the 1. ABC Umweltmessstelle â€” a special unit of the ABC Abwehr Korneuburg within the Austrian Armed Forces. The idea: a small, self-contained sensor box that can be mounted on virtually anything. A vehicle, a tripod, a robot â€” doesn't matter. It just measures and reports.
sections.problem: Professional CBRN detection equipment is expensive, bulky, and often locked into proprietary ecosystems. Field units need something they can deploy quickly, mount anywhere, and trust to deliver accurate readings without requiring specialized training.
sections.solution: A compact ESP32-based sensor box packing a Geiger-MÃ¼ller counter for radiation detection, a full suite of MQ gas sensors, and an Oâ‚‚ sensor. The box communicates over LoRa with a 2km range, streaming measurements to a handheld terminal. Universally mountable â€” it goes where the mission needs it.
sections.impact: A working prototype that proved off-the-shelf components can deliver reliable CBRN detection in the field. The universally mountable design means one box fits every deployment scenario the unit runs into.

grading-bot.title: Grading Bot
grading-bot.subtitle: Diploma Thesis
grading-bot.tagline: Submit your code, get your grade in 30 seconds. Live automated evaluation for Java, TypeScript, JavaScript, Bash, and PowerShell.
grading-bot.description: Automated code evaluation system supporting 5 languages with ~30s live grading â€” my diploma thesis, deployed at HTL Hollabrunn.

sections.context: This is my diploma thesis. Grading Bot is an automated code evaluation system running at HTL Hollabrunn. Students submit their assignments, and within about 30 seconds they get a grade and detailed feedback. It supports Java, TypeScript, JavaScript, Bash, and PowerShell â€” basically everything taught at the school.
sections.problem: Teachers were grading code by hand. Hundreds of submissions per assignment, multiple classes, every week. It was slow, inconsistent, and nobody enjoyed it. Students waited days for feedback that was often just a grade and a comment.
sections.solution: Each submission runs in its own Docker container â€” completely isolated, no way for student code to break anything. The system hooks into Azure AD for authentication and MS Teams for notifications. A teacher sets up the assignment once, and the bot handles the rest. About 30 seconds from submission to result.
sections.impact: Over 1,000 assignments graded automatically. Students get feedback while the code is still fresh in their heads. Teachers get their evenings back. It's live, it's fast, and it hasn't broken yet.

unleashed.title: Unleashed
unleashed.subtitle: Privacy-First Social (Discontinued)
unleashed.tagline: A privacy-first social platform built as a PWA. Shut down due to infrastructure costs, but the concept proved the idea works.
unleashed.description: A PWA social network experiment focused on privacy-first interaction â€” discontinued due to running costs.

sections.context: Unleashed was a social platform built as a Progressive Web App. The idea was simple: social media without the tracking, without the algorithmic manipulation, without selling your data. Just people connecting with people.
sections.problem: Every major social platform monetizes user data. Privacy settings are buried, algorithms decide what you see, and opting out means opting out of the platform entirely. There's no middle ground.
sections.solution: A PWA with zero-tracking architecture and end-to-end encryption. No algorithmic feed â€” you see posts chronologically from people you actually follow. Built with Kotlin and Jetpack Compose on the frontend, Supabase and Clerk on the backend.
sections.impact: The platform worked and proved the concept, but the infrastructure costs were too high to sustain as a solo project. It's been shut down, but the lessons learned about privacy-first architecture carry forward into every project I build.
